Fig. 102 Representative TEM images of the nanomaterials synthesized through spray pyrolysis. (a) Si nanocomposites (adapted from ref. 761 with permission from John Wiley and Sons, Copyright 1982), (b) B-hyperdoped Si NPs (adapted from ref. 778 with permission from John Wiley and Sons, Copyright 2019), (c) Ni NPs (adapted from ref. 816 with permission from American Chemical Society, Copyright 2005), (d) B NPs (adapted from ref. 762 with permission from John Wiley and Sons, Copyright 2016), (e) Fe/Fe2O3 core/shell nanomaterials (adapted from ref. 800 with permission from Elsevier, Copyright 2005), (f) TiO2/MWCNT nanocomposites (adapted from ref. 792 with permission from American Chemical Society, Copyright 2015), (g) TiO2/SnO2 nanocomposites (adapted from ref. 797 with permission from Elsevier, Copyright 2017), (h) rod-like ZnF2 nanomaterials (adapted from ref. 818 with permission from Elsevier, Copyright 2020), and (i) N-doped ZnS particles (adapted from ref. 818 with permission from Elsevier, Copyright 2020).

2.3.4.1. Silicon-based nanomaterials. Cannon, Danforth, Flint, Haggerty, and Mara were the pioneers of the laser pyrolysis synthesis technique.760,761 They first used it to synthesize, silicon, silicon carbide, and silicon nitride. They used silane as the silicon precursor. Because silane can absorb the energy of the laser at 10.6 m, there was no need to use any additional photosensitizer. In addition, they added ethylene (C2H4) and methane (CH4) to produce silicon carbide or ammonia (NH3) to produce silicon nitride. Both ethylene and ammonia could absorb the energy of the laser, while this was not possible for methane. In their set-up (Fig. 103), the gaseous precursors were introduced through a stainless-steel nozzle with an inner diameter of 1.5 mm. They used an argon stream at 400 sccm as a sheath gas surrounding the precursor inlet, which served not only to confine the gaseous precursors in a small zone, but also to quench the hot products to stop particle growth and limit the particle size. Moreover, a stream of argon at 600 sccm was directed at the KCl windows through which the laser entered the reactor, to cool them and keep them clean. A mechanical pump and throttling valve were used to control the pressure in the system in the range of 1.17 to 14.50 psia. The energy source was a 150 W laser with unfocused intensities from 270 to 1020 W cm2, from which focused intensities could reach 105 W cm2. They synthesized highly-pure, monodispersed, spherical, and loosely agglomerated NPs with sizes in the range of 10 to 100 nm and an average crystallite size of about 15 nm (Fig. 102a). Their production rates were about 1 g h1, and a maximum of about 10 g of NPs was synthesized during a run of the reactor. Increasing the laser power led to production of crystalline silicon NPs rather than amorphous ones. Notably, the fully dense silicon NPs did not possess any surface or internal porosity and were extremely pure with oxygen content below 0.1 wt%. The silicon carbide and silicon nitride NPs were in the ranges of 1826 and 1025 nm, respectively.760,761
Fig. 103 Schematic of the reactor developed by Cannon et al. to synthesize Si-containing NPs by laser pyrolysis. Adapted from ref. 760 with permission from John Wiley and Sons, Copyright 1982.

Decomposition of metal carbonyls such as iron carbonyl (Fe(CO)5), chromium carbonyl (Cr(CO)6), molybdenum carbonyl (Mo(CO)6), and tungsten carbonyl (W(CO)6) using this technique following the pioneering research of Cannon and coworkers demonstrated the versatility of the laser pyrolysis approach for synthesis of various nanomaterials.830

Ehbrecht and Huisken employed time-of-flight mass spectrometric analysis for in-flight characterization of silicon nanomaterials synthesized by pulsed laser pyrolysis of silane (SiH4) with a pulse energy of 50 mJ. They observed that the silicon nanomaterials consisted of Sin+ clusters in which n ranged from a few tens to several thousand. When n was between 22 and 100, the intermediate-size Sin clusters fragmented to yield Si6+-Si11+, while single Si+ and Si2+ ions were evaporated from the nanometric silicon clusters when the ionizing laser fluence was sufficiently high. They also observed multiply charged nanoclusters. Moreover, they found that the size of silicon clusters ejected from the pulsed source played a key role in their velocity which enabled use of a mechanical chopper in the path of the cluster beam to select different portions of the products of each pulse, which allowed them to use quasi-size-selected clusters for subsequent experiments.768 Hofmeister et al. employed the same synthesis system and studied the lattice contraction in silicon NPs. They observed that spherical monocrystalline silicon NPs possessed almost no planar lattice defects. The synthesized silicon NPs were covered by thin amorphous oxide shells that resulted in lattice contraction. Lattice contraction decreased with decreasing particle size and oxide thickness. Accordingly, the lattice contractions could be transformed to lattice dilatation of NPs with very small size. HRTEM images and the SAED pattern of these silicon NPs are presented in Fig. 104.769 Ledoux et al. used the same synthesis process and studied the size-dependent photoluminescence characteristics of silicon nanocrystals. They observed that the photoluminescence of the nanocrystalline silicon was in close agreement with a quantum confinement model. They concluded that the intrinsic photoluminescence quantum yield of the nanocrystalline silicon could reach almost 100%. A simple model described the silicon nanocrystal photoluminescence shift with air aging of the samples due to the decreasing size of the nanocrystalline core via self-limiting surface oxidation. The oxide layer covering the core silicon nanocrystals affected the lattice parameter which in turn effected the width of the photoluminescence emission spectrum, along with its peak position. This study was also helpful in explaining an astrophysical phenomenon of extended red emission, which was one of the authors goals.770,772,773


Fig. 104 Si NPs synthesized by Hofmeister et al. (a) HRTEM image of a monocrystalline silicon NP coated by an amorphous oxide layer. (b) SAED pattern. Adapted from ref. 769 with permission from Springer Nature, Copyright 1999.

Li et al. synthesized silicon NPs below 5 nm in diameter in macroscopic quantities (20200 mg h1) with intense visible photoluminescence after etching. They used silane as the main precursor with SF6 as a photosensitizer for more effective decomposition of silane. Hydrogen was used as the sheath gas to confine the reaction zone and was also added to the precursor stream to decrease the silane concentration, while a larger flow of He was used to purge the outer regions of the reactor and keep its windows free of particles. The laser power was 60 W and the pressure of the reaction chamber was typically 8 psia. Reducing the operating pressure below atmospheric pressure decreased the average particle size. They reported control of particle size, crystallinity, and production rate by changing the flow rates of hydrogen and helium to the reactor and by addition of SF6. They studied the effects of hydrogen flow rate in the central precursor flow and helium flow rate on the synthesis process and found that increasing either or both of these parameters decreased the average size of particles. Furthermore, they dispersed the silicon NPs in methanol then etched them with hydrofluoric acid (HF) to reduce the size of particles and passivate the silicon surface. Etching with HF produced particles with intense visible photoluminescence, while the as-synthesized NPs exhibited almost no photoluminescence.774

Cauchetier et al. synthesized Si/C/N nanocomposites by laser pyrolysis using ultrasonic spray delivery of aerosol droplets of hexamethyldisilazane ([(CH3)3Si]2NH) as a low-cost and effective precursor that could absorb the laser at 10.6 m. They employed a commercially-available ultrasonic spray generator (Pyrosol model from RBI, France) as illustrated in Fig. 105. They used a mixture of argon and ammonia or pure argon as the carrier gas. For the thermal decomposition, they used a 600 W industrial CO2 laser which produced a beam with a diameter of 13 mm. They collected the NPs on a cylindrical stainless-steel filter that was preheated and placed in a glass chamber. The nanocomposites were amorphous with average NP diameters of 30 to 60 nm. In addition, they investigated the effect of various operating parameters on the synthesis process and found that the total gas flow rate played the main role in increasing the NP production rate.780


Fig. 105 Schematic of the apparatus employed by Cauchetier et al. to synthesize Si/C/N nanocomposites. Adapted from ref. 780 with permission from John Wiley and Sons, Copyright 1994.

Herlin-Boime's group also advanced the synthesis of silicon carbide NPs by laser pyrolysis. They used a mixture of silane (SiH4) and ethylene (C2H4) as the precursors. Laser power was 600 W and the pressure was 14.31 psia. The production rate was 3.8 g h1 and the average size of the synthesized particles was 16.6 nm. Notably, they increased the silane to ethylene ratio in the precursor solution above the stoichiometric ratio to incorporate a slight excess of silicon in the final product to facilitate dispersion of the NPs in water by the generation of surface SiOH groups. In addition, they broke up agglomerates through magnetic stirring and wet ball-milling of the aqueous NP dispersion followed by slip-casting of slurries to obtain green bodies. They performed densification by spark plasma sintering at a pressure of 70 MPa which produced final densities of up to 96% of the theoretical full density.784 This group also synthesized uniformly carbon-coated silicon nanomaterials from the same precursors using a novel two-stage laser pyrolysis approach. Fig. 106 presents a schematic of their reactor. Silane (SiH4) was introduced to the first reaction zone to synthesize crystalline silicon NPs. They could control the size of silicon nanocrystals by adjusting the flow rate of helium as the diluting gas and focusing the laser. The silicon nanocrystals were delivered to the second reaction zone where the decomposition of ethylene (C2H4), injected after the first reaction zone, produced a carbon shell around the silicon nanocrystals. Notably, they adjusted the laser power between the two reaction zones in a way that ensured crystallinity of the silicon produced in the first zone while the remaining laser power was adequate to drive decomposition of the ethylene in the second zone. They saw no evidence of formation of silicon carbide at the interface of the core and shell. In addition, the synthesis in a single-step continuous process instead of a multi-step batch synthesis reduced the presence of silicon oxide in the final products, which in turn made the nanomaterials promising for lithium-ion battery anode applications. The carbon-coated silicon nanocomposites provided a high and stable capacity because of the protective effect of the carbon shell, which prevented direct contact of the silicon core with the electrolyte.782 In another study, they controlled the experimental conditions to synthesize the amorphous Si@C nanocomposites using the same strategy. Because the silicon nanocrystals used as an anode material were amorphized during the first charge/discharge cycle, which negatively impacted stability, the initially amorphous carbon-coated silicon nanocomposites provided more stable capacity. Notably, they created the carbon shell with a thickness of 1 nm, which was sufficient to prevent oxidation of the amorphous silicon core which is more easily oxidized than crystalline silicon. In doing so, they improved the properties of the nanocomposites for lithium-ion battery applications.783


Fig. 106 Schematic of the novel two-step laser pyrolysis reactor employed by Sourice et al. to synthesize Si@C nanocomposites. Reproduced from ref. 782 with permission from American Chemical Society, Copyright 2015.

Hyperdoping, which means doping to concentrations above the nominal equilibrium solubility of the dopant, extends the range of electronic properties that can be obtained from a semiconductor. Rohani et al. employed the laser pyrolysis technique, which is capable of producing strongly non-equilibrium conditions where doping is governed by kinetics instead of thermodynamics, to synthesize spherical boron-hyperdoped silicon NPs with an average size around 25 nm. The precursor mixture was composed of silane (SiH4) and diborane (B2H6). The hyperdoping with boron did not alter the diamond cubic structure of silicon nanocrystals. The hyperdoped NPs exhibited tunable LSPR and were stable in air for long periods (minimum one year). Moreover, the synthesized NPs retained their structure without B segregation upon annealing at up to 600 C.778


2.3.4.2. Boron-based nanomaterials. Boulanger et al. synthesized graphitic boron nitride NPs using laser pyrolysis. The precursor mixture included boron trichloride (BCl3) and ammonia (NH3) which was thermally decomposed by an industrial high-power CO2 laser. They investigated the morphology of the NPs with and without heat treatment at temperatures from 1000 to 1650 C. The as-synthesized NPs were roughly spherical with concentric graphitic shells and sizes from 20 to above 100 nm. The smaller as-synthesized particles with average sizes of 20 to 50 nm were mainly nested polyhedra that consisted of about 40 concentric shells near the center, and were considered as filled-to-the-center. The larger particles with average sizes above 100 nm consisted of about 10 graphitic layers with large empty spaces in the structures and were considered hollow particles. After thermal treatment under a nitrogen atmosphere at 1100 C, the same morphology for all particles, with a larger diameter above 200 nm, was observed. Further treatment under the same atmosphere at temperatures of 14001650 C produced nanoplatelets with 10 to 50 graphitic layers and typical lateral dimensions of 50 nm, which were highly stable and remained unchanged for several months.763

Rohani et al. used laser pyrolysis to create boron NPs for use in hydrogen generation by water-splitting (ideally, 2 B + 3 H2O B2O3 + 3 H2). Among water-reactive metals, boron has the highest theoretical specific capacity for hydrogen generation by reaction with water. To achieve complete reaction of boron, they needed highly-active boron NPs with high purity, small size, and high specific surface area, which can be produced by laser pyrolysis. They used diborane (B2H6) as the precursor and SF6 as the photosensitizer to generate boron NPs. The NPs were oxide free, amorphous, highly pure, air stable, and formed stable dispersion in water and alcohols. Because boron hydrolysis is not a spontaneous reaction, they needed an activator to launch the reaction. Among various possibilities tested, NaH was found to produce the greatest amount of hydrogen. The hydrogen generated by boron hydrolysis was used in a fuel cell, where its performance was very close to that of pure hydrogen from a compressed gas cylinder. Although in this case the total H2 generation did not reach the theoretical stoichiometric limit, it exceeded the theoretical limit for competing materials including silicon and aluminum, and thus shows great promise. These demonstrations also show that no reaction byproducts were generated that would affect the performance of fuel cells.762


2.3.4.3. Carbon-based nanomaterials. Herlin et al. employed laser pyrolysis to generate carbon-based nanomaterials from hydrocarbon precursors such as ethylene (C2H4) or butyne (C4H6). They found that by changing the reaction temperature they could synthesize nanomaterials with various characteristics. Amorphous carbon-based materials were produced at temperatures below 1200 K. The IR spectra of these materials had a broad continuum absorbance with stronger peaks associated with CC and CH aromatic groups. However, synthesis at higher temperatures resulted concentric microtexture nanomaterials which exhibited only a continuum with negligible features in the IR spectra. They suggested that the hydrogen content played a central role in appearance of these peaks in the more amorphous nanomaterials. They went on to conclude that IR laser pyrolysis synthesis of carbon-based nanomaterials followed a similar mechanism as the generation of carbon dusts in the envelopes of evolved carbon-rich stars.765 This group also investigated the synthesis of highly-aromatic carbon NPs by laser pyrolysis of hydrocarbons as a function of laser power and found that increasing the temperature of the reaction zone by increasing the laser power led to evolution of more turbostratic concentric carbon NPs from poorly organized ones.766
2.3.4.4. Magnetic nanomaterials. Bi et al. employed laser pyrolysis to generate iron-containing NPs including -Fe, Fe3C, and Fe7C3. A schematic of their reactor system is shown in Fig. 107. The iron precursor was iron carbonyl (Fe(CO)5) delivered from a bubbler by a flow of ethylene. Because the ethylene can absorb the laser at 10.6 m, it served as both photosensitizer and carrier gas and, in the case of carbide particles, as the carbon source as well. They controlled the operating parameters to synthesize NPs with different chemical compositions. Increasing the laser power from 30 to 50 W and the chamber pressure from 1.93 to 5.80 psia while decreasing the nozzle diameter from 1.7 to 0.8 mm resulted in Fe3C rather than -Fe. Further increasing the laser power from 50 to 54 W, the chamber pressure from 5.80 psi to 9.67 psi, and the flow rate of ethylene from 9 to 25 sccm while decreasing the width of the beam from 1 mm to 0.2 mm produced Fe7C3 instead of Fe3C. The NPs were collected in a Pyrex trap with a stack of ferrite magnets that drew the ferromagnetic particles away from a Teflon membrane filter. Notably, they performed in situ passivation by flowing 4 to 10% oxygen in helium through the collection trap, which avoided spontaneous combustion of the NPs (-Fe in particular) upon exposure to air. In addition, they placed a thermocouple inside the collection trap to monitor the process and prevent runaway oxidation. The average size of the NPs was in the range of 5 to 30 nm. The production rate for Fe3C7 NPs was about 3 g h1, illustrating the versatility of the technique for relatively high-rate synthesis of NPs. Flowing excess ethylene led to carbon coating of the Fe3C and Fe7C3 NPs. Moreover, they investigated the magnetic properties of the NPs and found that they were ferromagnetic, rather than superparamagnetic, despite their small size.798
Fig. 107 Schematic of the system employed by Bi et al. to synthesize Fe-containing NPs. Adapted from ref. 798 with permission from Springer Nature, Copyright 1993.

Veintemillas-Verdaguer et al. synthesized crystalline -Fe2O3 NPs with a high degree of purity and a low degree of aggregation with an average particle size of 5 nm. The precursor was 30% iron pentacarbonyl (Fe(CO)5) in isopropanol (C3H8O). They nebulized the precursor solution and delivered aerosol droplets to the reaction zone where a 100 W continuous wave CO2 laser beam with a diameter of 4 mm induced decomposition and particle formation. The production rate was in the range of 33 to 96 mg h1. The product yield, defined as the amount of the NPs synthesized relative to the iron pentacarbonyl delivered, ranged from 12 to 84%. Moreover, they investigated the magnetic properties of the NPs and observed superparamagnetism at ambient temperature with a saturation magnetization of 30.5 emu g1. The size of the NPs played a substantial role in their magnetic characteristics, especially for particles below 10 nm in diameter. For such NPs, enhanced coercivity could arise from extra anisotropy in addition to magentocrystalline anisotropy due to the high surface to volume ratio.810 This group used the colloidal suspensions of iron oxide NPs as contrast agents in MRI after coating them with dextran (C8H32O16) in an aqueous sodium citrate (Na3C6H5O7) solution. The magnetic properties and 1H NMR relaxation times of the suspensions demonstrated their potential as contrast agents for MRI. They found that the greatest saturation magnetization was observed for the largest particles with the largest crystallite size, although all cases exhibited superparamagnetic behavior at room temperature.811 In another study, this group used metallic iron NPs synthesized by laser pyrolysis in addition to the iron oxide NPs as contrast agents for MRI applications after formulating them as biocompatible ferrofluids. For laser pyrolysis synthesis of iron oxide NPs, they flowed air together with argon to clean the ZnSe windows, while they performed slight oxidation by flowing nitrogen with 1 ppm of oxygen in the case of metallic iron NPs, which led to the synthesis of stable metal core particles with high crystallinity, covered by a thin oxide layer. Accordingly, they produced a stable ferrofluid of the sub-10 nm metal particles in aggregates of about 50 nm. The metallic iron NPs provided greater saturation magnetization and susceptibility than the iron oxide-based suspensions. In addition to increasing crystal size, using metallic iron NPs instead of iron oxide was a key factor in increasing the relaxivity value, the key parameter for MRI contrast.799 In addition, they compared the iron NPs covered by a thin layer of iron oxide with commercially available iron oxide in MRI applications in small animals and found that the laser pyrolysis synthesized samples produced a negative contrast enhancement of 60% in the liver compared to the commercially available iron oxide contrast agent, demonstrating their advantages as a contrast agent for liver and spleen MRI.800 They also investigated the mechanism of dextran adsorption on the surface of Fe2O3 NPs synthesized by laser pyrolysis and compared the strength of bonding in the case of laser pyrolysis synthesis with coprecipitation synthesis. They found that the favored mechanism is the collective hydrogen bonding between the iron oxide surface and dextran hydroxyl groups. They observed a strong bond between the iron oxide NPs and dextran in the case of heating dry samples of the suspensions of laser-pyrolysis-synthesized samples, while such a bond was not observed in the samples produced by a solution-phase coprecipitation approach. This difference led to better dispersion of the laser pyrolysis derived samples. Accordingly, they suggested that the coating of dextran on the surface of iron NPs is more effective for samples synthesized at higher temperatures and shorter times, which resulted in permanent dextran linkage to the particles.812 Furthermore, this group performed acid treatment with nitric acid (HNO3) on iron oxide NPs with sizes below 5 nm synthesized by laser pyrolysis to increase the saturation magnetization by 40% and enhance the initial susceptibility. Additionally, the optimized acid treatment led to a decrease in the aggregate size, increase in surface charge density, and improved colloidal stability.815

A laser pyrolysis synthesis of nickel NPs was presented by Swihart and coworkers. They used nickel carbonyl (Ni(CO)4) as the main precursor. Although nickel carbonyl has a high vapor pressure and its decomposition will lead to the synthesis of pure nickel NPs, it is very toxic which limits its safe use as a gaseous precursor. To circumvent this issue, they used in situ generation of nickel carbonyl by flowing CO through hydrogen-regenerated nickel powder in a tube furnace. Fig. 108 presents a schematic of their experimental set-up. A helium gas stream was used as a sheath gas to confine the reaction zone. Because the nickel carbonyl cannot absorb the laser at 10.6 m, a photosensitizer is necessary. Very high specific surface area NPs with a mean diameter of less than 10 nm are prone to oxidization upon exposure to air. Hence, larger particles were targeted to study the effects of parameters on the size and morphology. However, because smaller NPs with the size less than 10 nm have the most interesting magnetic behavior, they also synthesized smaller particles. The NPs were loosely agglomerated and dispersible in nonpolar solvents, but did not form long-term stable colloidal dispersions. They studied the effect of CO flow rate, inert gas, photosensitizer, and precursor concentration on the synthesis process. Additionally, they studied the magnetic properties of nickel NPs. They reported the flow rate of carbon monoxide changes the nickel carbonyl concentration, delivery rate, and flow patterns in the reactor. The choice of inert gas affects the reaction time and appearance of a visible flame in the reaction zone. They used both SF6 and C2H4 as photosensitizers and found that although a high flow rate of SF6 led to high reaction temperature, it caused fluoride and sulfur contamination in the product. Use of C2H4 as the photosensitizer led to a change of morphology and crystal structure and eliminated sulfur and fluorine contamination. Finally, they found that laser pyrolysis synthesized nickel NPs with a size below 8 nm exhibit superparamagnetism.816


Fig. 108 Schematic of the reactor system used by He et al. to synthesize Ni NPs. Reproduced from ref. 816 with permission from American Chemical Society, Copyright 2005.

2.3.4.5. Titanium-based nanomaterials. Simon et al. synthesized nitrogen-doped titanium monoxide in a single-step laser pyrolysis process. They used liquid titanium tetraisopropoxide (Ti[OCH(CH3)2]4) as the precursor, which was atomized by a Pyrosol system and delivered to the reaction zone by nitrogen carrier gas, which had a much lower thermal diffusivity and led to better confinement of the reactants compared to helium. They supplied a low flow of ammonia (NH3) just before the outlet of the injecting nozzle to serve as both photosensitizer and nitrogen source. They increased the residence time in the reaction zone by reducing the total flow rates of gaseous streams, to increase decomposition of the reactants and generate reducing species from ammonia decomposition to incorporate nitrogen atoms as a dopant in the NPs. The laser power was 1 kW and a production rate of 1.44 g h1 was obtained from 6.35 g h1 of the titanium precursor. The product particles had the rock-salt crystal structure and an average size of 7 to 9 nm. Doping with nitrogen led to enhanced photocatalytic activity by reducing the optical band gap into the visible range of the solar spectrum. Notably, the as-synthesized nanopowder contained carbon, which was obvious from its black color, but it could be removed by mild heat treatment in air. Such heat treatment also partially or fully converted the rock-salt structure to the anatase phase by oxidation to a stoichiometry closer to TiO2.789

Herlin-Boime's group synthesized TiO2/MWCNT nanocomposites by in situ and ex situ processes based on laser pyrolysis. For the in situ synthesis, they mixed titanium tetraisopropoxide (Ti[OCH(CH3)2]4) with MWCNT dispersed in toluene (C7H8) to make a precursor solution for a single-step laser pyrolysis synthesis by on-flight growth of titania NPs on the surface of MWCNT. In separate experiments they used titanium tetraisopropoxide as the precursor to synthesize titania NPs by laser pyrolysis and mixed the product powder with MWCNT to prepare ex situ formed TiO2/MWCNT nanocomposites. As evident in Fig. 109, in the case of in situ synthesis, the coating of titania on the MWCNT was highly dense so that there was almost no bare MWCNT surface, while ex situ mixing produced only partial coating of titania on the surface of MWCNT. The in situ synthesis by laser pyrolysis improved the electronic interactions between the two components of the nanocomposites. Moreover, the MWCNT dispersion in the titania NPs was significantly enhanced in the in situ synthesis. The titania, in situ TiO2/MWCNT, and ex situ TiO2/MWCNT had average diameters of 12, 13, and 12 nm and surface areas of 122, 166, and 120 m2 g1, respectively. They employed the laser pyrolysis synthesized nanomaterials for solar cell applications and found that using in situ synthesized TiO2/MWCNT nanocomposites as the active layer in porous photoelectrodes led to a 20% improvement in the efficiency of solid-state dye-sensitized solar cells because of a higher short-circuit current density compared to the result using ex situ synthesized ones. Reduced charge recombination and the intimate electronic interaction between the NPs and nanotubes enhanced the charge extraction to the photoelectrode.792


Fig. 109 TEM images of TiO2/MWCNT nanocomposites synthesized by Wang et al. through laser pyrolysis by: (a) in situ process and (b) ex situ processes. Adapted from ref. 792 with permission from American Chemical Society, Copyright 2015.

Herlin-Boime's group synthesized pure titania, nitrogen-doped titania, gold-doped titania, and gold-modified nitrogen-doped titania NPs following the laser pyrolysis synthesis procedures they developed for the other titania-containing NPs and investigated their photocatalytic activity. They used titanium tetraisopropoxide (Ti[OCH(CH3)2]4), hydrogen tetrachloroaurate trihydrate (HAuCl43H2O), and ammonia (NH3) as the precursors. They monitored the destruction of formic acid (HCOOH) under UV and visible light irradiation to test the photocatalytic activity of the various laser pyrolysis synthesized NPs and compared them with one another and with commercially available titania. They reported that all the laser pyrolysis synthesized samples showed enhanced photocatalytic activity compared to commercially available titania under UV irradiation. In addition, the laser pyrolysis synthesized samples with even very low content of gold performed better than pure titania in the degradation of formic acid under UV light. Finally, they observed that the gold-modified nitrogen-doped titania samples exhibited superior photocatalytic activity under visible light compared to the nitrogen-doped titania samples.790

Scarisoreanu et al. employed a single-step laser pyrolysis technique to produce TiO2/SnO2 nanocomposites. They used two bubblers to separately deliver titanium tetrachloride (TiCl4) and tin tetrachloride (SnCl4) as precursors and carried them into the reaction zone in a mixture of argon and air to facilitate their oxidization. Because none of these streams could absorb the energy of the CO2 laser at 10.6 m, they introduced ethylene (C2H4) as a photosensitizer. They produced nanocomposites with various tin concentrations from 1.1 to 4.8 at%. The nanocomposites contained both anatase and rutile titania, but anatase was the major component. The average crystallite sizes were in the range of 8 to 22 nm. They investigated the photocatalytic activity of the nanocomposites for degradation of methyl orange under UV irradiation and found that the nanocomposites with tin atomic concentrations in the range of 1.8 to 4.8% exhibited greater photoactivity compared to commercially available titania powder, and all the nanocomposites possessed a lower band gap energy.797


2.3.4.6. Zinc-based nanomaterials. In recent work, we have developed a low-cost ultrasonic atomizer that enabled us to spray any stable precursor solution into the reaction zone for the synthesis of nanomaterials with various compositions. A schematic of the ultrasonic atomizer is presented in Fig. 110a. We synthesized an array of zinc containing NPs including zinc oxide, pristine zinc sulfide, nitrogen-doped zinc sulfide, and zinc fluoride. To synthesize zinc oxide, zinc acetate dihydrate (Zn(CH3COO)22H2O) was dissolved in deionized water as the precursor solution. Because this precursor cannot absorb the energy of the laser, we introduced SF6 as a photosensitizer. The uniform zinc oxide NPs had the wurtzite crystalline structure and sizes below 10 nm. Increasing the flow rate of SF6 and the laser power led to production of zinc fluoride NPs using the same precursor solution. Further tuning of the operating parameters led to formation of zinc fluoride NPs with two different morphologies: spherical and rod-like. To synthesize NPs with rod-like shape, we increased the laser power and the SF6 flow rate compared to the conditions used to produce spherical NPs. In addition, the sheath gas used for the former case was hydrogen instead of nitrogen, which led to more rapid quenching because of its higher thermal conductivity. To synthesize pristine zinc sulfide, we added thioacetamide (CH3CSNH2) to the aqueous solution of zinc acetate dihydrate and sprayed it into the reaction zone, which led to production of zinc sulfide NPs with sphalerite crystalline structure and sizes below 10 nm, with a relatively narrow size distribution compared to the other vapor-phase synthesized nanomaterials. Adding thiourea (NH2CSNH2) instead of thioacetamide to the zinc acetate dihydrate aqueous solution resulted the formation of nitrogen-doped zinc sulfide NPs which had a narrower band gap compared to the pristine zinc sulfide, potentially extending their photocatalytic activity under visible light irradiation. By adjusting the operating parameters, we were able to synthesize nitrogen-doped zinc sulfide with different combinations of crystalline structures: sphalerite- and wurtzite-rich. Because the synthesis of the wurtzite crystalline structure requires higher temperature in the reaction zone compared to the synthesis of sphalerite, we increased the flow rate of SF6 and the laser power for this purpose. The relatively low vapor pressure of thiourea led to the formation of microspheres by a droplet-to-particle conversion mechanism rather than by gas-to-particle conversion as observed for the other materials. The morphologies of the various synthesized zinc-containing NPs are presented in Fig. 110bg. All in all, the newly-developed low-cost ultrasonic atomizer should extend the utility of the laser pyrolysis by expanding the array of precursors that can be used with low-power, widely available CO2 laser sources.818
Fig. 110 (a) Schematic of the ultrasonic atomizer employed by Malekzadeh et al. to synthesize Zn-containing nanomaterials by laser pyrolysis: (1) metal mesh disc with piezoelectric disk, (2) electronic driver circuit for piezoelectric element, (3) precursor solution injection port, (4) return line to pump, (5) precursor supply line from pump, (6) carrier gas inlet, and (7) aerosol droplets of precursor solution outlet to the reaction zone. TEM images of (b) pristine ZnS, (c) sphalerite-rich N-doped ZnS, (d) wurtzite-rich N-doped ZnS, (e) ZnO, (f) rod-like ZnF2, and (g) spherical ZnF2. Insets present the corresponding SAED patterns. Adapted from ref. 818 with permission from Elsevier, Copyright 2020.

2.3.4.7. Instrumentation and modelling. Kruis et al. developed a simple model to describe the evolution of particle size, morphology, and number concentration during simultaneous sintering and coagulation in an aerosol flow reactor that neglected the polydispersity of primary and aggregated NPs. They considered the effect of irregular/fractal structure on the collision kernel from the free molecular to the continuum regime. This simple model was in good agreement with a computationally-demanding two-dimensional sectional model for the aggregates with respect to both the specific surface area and the primary particle volume. They applied the model to the synthesis of silicon from silane (SiH4) in a laser pyrolysis reactor. They found that grain boundary diffusion was the main coalescence mechanism for the silicon NPs, based upon their theoretical evaluation of different sintering mechanisms. Moreover, the model showed that growth of primary particles through sintering was possible at temperatures well below the melting point. The results from the model were in reasonable agreement with experimental data for the primary particle sizes, suggesting that the sintering process was accurately represented. Notably, they accounted for the production of smaller and more aggregated silicon NPs produced by the laser pyrolysis based on the assumption that the outer boundaries of the laser-heated region were cooled and diluted by the surrounding unheated sheath gas.831

Bomat-Miguel et al. employed a simple coagulation model to simulate the synthesis of NPs by laser pyrolysis. The model had only the coagulation time as a tunable parameter. They considered the laser pyrolysis synthesis of iron NPs as a case study, for which they collected substantial experimental data. They applied the model to find operating conditions that maximized productivity as function of particle size. They found that the pressure and the carrier gas flow were the main factors determining productivity for larger NPs with mean diameter above 20 nm, while the vapor pressure of the precursor (temperature of delivery system) played the main role in determining productivity for smaller NPs with diameters below 20 nm.832

Mwakikunga derived two equations to describe their experimental observations for the flame temperature trends based upon laser power and laser wavelength in laser pyrolysis synthesis using spray-based precursor delivery. They considered the thermal decomposition of tungsten ethoxide (C12H30O6W) and vanadium ethoxide (C6H15O4V) aerosols through CO2 laser pyrolysis as case studies. The first equation, to find the flame temperature trend as a function of laser power, was extended from the original HaggertyCannon energy balance equation.833 The HaggertyCannon equation equates the energy absorbed from the laser beam to the total energies used to raise the aerosol temperature and initiate the chemical reactions plus energy losses through radiation, convection, and conduction. Based upon this equation, they concluded that the conversion of the precursors into product nanostructures was driven by a small fraction of the overall laser power, which was in a good agreement with experimental data. Moreover, they attempted to precisely identify the formation enthalpies and heat capacities through both modelling and experiment results, obtaining surprisingly low values of the heat capacities of the droplets, with ethanol as the solvent. This paper raises interesting questions about assumptions of thermal equilibrium during the laser pyrolysis process that merit further consideration.834

Dang and Swihart developed a fully-coupled two-dimensional model to investigate the laser pyrolysis synthesis of silicon NPs from silane. The model included laser heating, fluid dynamics, gas phase and surface phase chemical reactions, and aerosol dynamics (NP transport and evolution through convection, diffusion, nucleation, surface growth, thermophoresis, and coagulation processes). They simulated the aerosol dynamics using a moment method, assuming a lognormal particle size distribution, and using a sectional model and compared the results from these two methods. They found that although only the sectional model was able to predict the local bimodal size distribution occurring at some points within the reactor, the moment method was able to predict the final product characteristics as well as the sectional method at much lower computational cost. They also performed a parametric study to find the influence of various operating parameters such as laser intensity, gas phase composition, inlet gas velocity, and the concentration of precursor on the final product characteristics. They observed that increasing the temperature of the reaction zone resulted in an increase in the size of the NPs as well as silane conversion. Also, increasing the inlet gas velocity led to a decrease in the size of NPs and silane conversion due to the shorter residence time in the hot zone of the reactor. Moreover, increasing the concentration of hydrogen reduced both gas phase and surface reaction rates. Accordingly, it reduced the rate of particles formation and thus had a similar effect to an increase in the gas inlet velocity. Furthermore, they investigated the effects of the interconnected mechanisms on the synthesis of NPs. They reported that variation in the reaction conditions for different pathways through the three-dimensional reactor domain played the main role in determining size polydispersity and creating non-lognormal overall size distributions.835 In another study, they considered three sub-models to develop the simulation method: (i) They modeled the chemically reacting flow inside the reactor spatially with full geometric detail, without the consideration of aerosol dynamics, and with highly-simplified chemistry. (ii) Then, they employed an axisymmetric two-dimensional CFD model to describe the reaction zone, in which the results from the first step were used to find the boundary conditions. (iii) Finally, the synthesis of silicon NPs was investigated through a two-dimensional aerosol dynamics model by the consideration of more complete silane decomposition chemistry, along with the velocities and temperatures obtained from the second step. They employed a bivariate model to simulate the particle size evolution and morphology, and a moment model, based upon a lognormal particle volume distribution. Moreover, CFD simulation to incorporate the fluid dynamics data into the aerosol model made it appropriate for applications with complex reactor geometries. The model predicted that spherical NPs were generated at high temperature at the center of the reaction zone, followed by aggregation downstream of the reaction zone to generate non-spherical larger aggregates. In addition, they reported that thermophoresis plays a crucial role in the laser pyrolysis synthesis process because the small volume heated at the intersection of the laser beam and photosensitizer inlet stream resulted in steep temperature gradients.836 While most of these dynamics are similar to those observed in flame synthesis, the laser pyrolysis process combines some aspects of both a premixed flame, with energy deposition across the radius of the hot zone with aspects of a diffusion flame, with steep radial temperature gradients, and thus has some unique features.

3. Conclusions

In this review, we classified vapor-phase nanosynthesis methods into three categories based on the chemical similarity between the initial precursors and final products: (a) physically-based vapor-phase nanosynthesis methods in which the chemical structure of the initial precursors and final products are similar, including inert gas condensation, spark discharge generation, and pulsed laser ablation. These methods use direct heating, electrical discharges, intense laser light, or other methods to vaporize the precursor and then nucleate NPs of the same material or a simple compound of it. Generally, synthesis of highly-pure nanomaterials is the main benefit of these approaches and the limitations on the batch size or production rate per unit time are the major shortcomings of these approaches; (b) plasma processing nanosynthesis methods which can use precursors that are chemically similar to the final product, or molecular precursors that are quite different from the final product. Within this class, we distinguish between cases in which the precursors are injected into or downstream of a high-temperature plasma with thermal equilibrium between the electrons and ionized gas, and those using non-thermal plasmas in which the electrons have much higher temperatures than the ionized gas. In general, rapid heating and cooling rate in plasma is the main advantage of these approaches, while the need for complex equipment is the major barrier to broader use of these methods; (c) chemically-based vapor-phase nanosynthesis methods in which the initial precursors possess a different chemical structure compared to the final products include chemical vapor condensation, spray pyrolysis, flame-based aerosol synthesis, and laser pyrolysis. In each of these methods, a vapor or liquid droplets containing molecular (usually metalorganic or metal salt) precursors are decomposed following energy input, from furnace walls, a flame, or a laser. High production rate is a key advantage of many of these methods, while complex mechanisms and difficulty in achieving a high degree of purity can be limitations in these processes. In addition to the brief introduction of each method and the summarization of interesting nanomaterials produced using them, we described in detail some of the highest-impact studies that have been published about these methods, highlighting the corresponding applications of the nanomaterials produced.

Overall, although solution-phase methods of nanomaterial synthesis, including hydrothermal, solvothermal, solgel, and related processes play a dominant role in the scientific literature on nanomaterial synthesis, vapor-phase routes can provide a very fruitful alternative that can dramatically reduce the use of solvents and generation of waste, and that can be conducted in a steady-state continuous operation mode that is typical of industrial chemical processing. The present review aims to demonstrate the wide range of possibilities and of materials that can be prepared by these vapor-phase routes. While it is extensive, it is by no means comprehensive, and many more worthwhile studies have been published. For each synthesis route, and particularly for the more complex ones including plasma processes, flame processes, and laser-driven processes, there is much room remaining for both advances in fundamental understanding that will enable predictive modelling and scale-up, and for creative application to new materials and, especially, material combinations produced in a single-step continuous process.

Despite the decades of development described in this review, many opportunities for further advances in vapor-phase synthesis remain. Rapid advances in computer science and simulation methods, along with increasing computational power are improving our ability predict the formation of NPs in vapor-phase techniques using advanced modelling techniques. These advances move the field ever closer to the elusive ability to fully model industrial-scale processes that couple turbulent reactive flow and steep temperature and concentration gradients with NP nucleation, growth, aggregation, and coalescence, linking processes over many orders of magnitude in length and time scales. At the same time, new experimental developments are expanding the ability of researchers and practitioners to adopt these vapor-phase synthesis approaches. For example, we recently combined the ultrasonic atomization technique with laser pyrolysis to demonstrate a low-cost, green, and single-step route to synthesize fluorine-containing compounds with interesting properties.818 This is only a representative example of how the combination of techniques, in this case spray pyrolysis (using aerosol delivery of one precursor), CVC (using vapor-phase delivery of another precursor), and laser pyrolysis (using laser heating) can provide routes to synthesize new materials with interesting properties for existing and emerging applications. Similarly, advances in preparation of multi-component nanomaterials, particularly in the realm of catalysis, provide abundant opportunities for developing both materials and processes.31,837 Multi-stage aerosol processes, like the two-stage laser pyrolysis method of Herlin-Boime and co-workers (Fig. 106)782 and the two-stage non-thermal plasma reactor of Mangolini and co-workers354 provide new opportunities to further tailor multicomponent materials in vapor-phase synthesis. Hard- and soft-templating strategies and ligand-capping strategies developed for solution-phase synthesis methods can be brought into the gas phase, particularly in spray pyrolysis and related methods that involve droplet-to-particle conversion. Numerous other combinations of synthesis techniques can similarly open up opportunities to produce new and interesting nanomaterials, and to economically scale up the production of these materials to achieve economical and societal impact.

List of definitions

Agglomeration: agglomeration is the process in which NPs collide and adhere to one another relatively weakly, forming soft aggregates that can be simply broken through mechanical forces.838,839

Aggregation: aggregation is the process in which NPs collide and adhere to one another strongly, via interfacial reaction or partial coalescence, to form larger and relatively dense aggregates.838 It depends on both particle transport mechanisms and interfacial chemical reactions.840

Annealing: annealing is a heat treatment process usually applied to reduce crystal defects and/or increase ductility and malleability.841 Annealing is usually done an inert atmosphere.

Calcination: calcination is a heat treatment often intended to increase the crystallinity of NPs and remove impurities on their surface.842 It is generally done in an oxidizing atmosphere.

Coalescence: coalescence is a process in which merging and mixing of particles leads to homogeneous NPs.843 Liquid droplets always coalesce upon collision, but solid NPs may also coalesce at temperatures below their melting point. Partial coalescence leads to the formation of hard aggregates.27

Coagulation: coagulation can be taken as synonymous with agglomeration as defined above.844 Coagulation leads to the formation of loose agglomerates.27

Droplet-to-particle conversion: droplet-to-particle conversion is the dominant mechanism for the synthesis of NPs when aerosol droplets of precursor solutions react to form product particles without evaporating.818 It leads to relatively large, spherical particles, which may be hollow or porous.

Fragmentation: fragmentation is the process of breaking of aggregates into smaller clusters.845

Gas-to-particle conversion: gas-to-particle conversion is the dominant mechanism for forming NPs from gaseous precursors or when aerosol droplets of precursor solutions first evaporate and then react in the gas phase.818

Nucleation: nucleation is a self-limiting process that relieves supersaturation (thermodynamic driving force for phase change) by spontaneous formation of new particles.846,847

Primary particles: the small quasi-spherical particles that initially form by gas-to-particle conversion or that make up aggregates.

Sintering: sintering, in the context of material processing, is the compacting of the particles to form a solid mass through heat and/or pressure without melting.848 However, in the context of NP synthesis, it is often used as a synonym for coalescence.

Surface growth: surface growth is an irreversible process in which particles grow by condensation or reaction of vapor-phase species on their surface.849 It tends to yield equal growth rates for particles of all sizes, and thus narrows the relative width of the particle size distribution.

Self-assembly: self-assembly is the process of spontaneous organization of nanoscale building blocks into ordered structures.850

Thermophoresis: thermophoresis is a phenomenon in which a macroscopic temperature gradient drives transport of aerosol particles from a higher to lower temperature region.851

List of acronyms

NPNanoparticle
TEMTransmission electron microscopy
SAEDSelected area electron diffraction
SEMScanning electron microscopy
HRTEMHigh-resolution transmission electron microscopy
APTAtom probe tomography
TGAThermal gravimetric analysis
IGCInert gas condensation
CVCChemical vapor condensation
VAFSVapor-fed aerosol flame synthesis
LAFSLiquid-fed aerosol flame synthesis
FSPFlame spray pyrolysis
FASPFlame-assisted spray pyrolysis
SWCNTSingle-wall carbon nanotube
MWCNTMulti-wall carbon nanotube
SWCNHSingle-wall carbon nanohorn
BNNTBoron nitride nanotube
HPCHierarchial porous carbon
LSPRLocalized surface plasmon resonance
SEISpecific energy input
MDMolecular dynamics
CFDComputational fluid dynamics
QMOMQuadrature method of moments
PSDFParticle size distribution function

Conflicts of interest

There are no conflicts to declare.
